<summary>

- Modern nasal surgery aims to enhance cosmetic appearance and improve natural nose functions, including respiration.
- Acoustic rhinometry (AR) is a common method for measuring nasal cavity geometry, which has a close correlation with rhinomanometry.
- AR uses analysis of reflected acoustic impulses to measure nasal cavity dimensions, including cross-sectional area and volume.
- Factors such as race, age, sex, height, weight, and smoking habits can influence nose geometry.
- The study evaluated changes in nasal dimensions of healthy Iranian volunteers after cosmetic rhinoplasty using AR and compared pre- and post-surgery measurements.
- The study included healthy volunteers aged 18-40 without prior nose surgery, fracture, allergy, asthma, or sinus disorders.
- The study used AR to measure nasal dimensions before and after surgery, focusing on length, minimal cross-sectional area (MCA), and volume of each nasal cavity.
- The study found that MCA1 and d1 increased, while MCA2 and d2 decreased after surgery, with more significant changes in the decongested state.
- AR is a reliable and objective method for determining functional and geometric changes in the nasal cavity, and it can provide less variability of results than rhinomanometry.

</summary>

<summary>

- Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in economically developed nations, and its incidence is increasing. Ongoing research aims to prevent the early development of cardiovascular risk factors such as atherosclerosis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic inflammation, and insulin resistance.
- N-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) have been shown to have beneficial effects on cardiovascular health in observational and experimental studies. They were initially used for the treatment of dyslipidemic disorders due to their lipid-lowering action, but their anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, antiatherosclerotic, and antiarrhythmogenic effects were later discovered.
- Low-grade chronic inflammation is a prominent process in the development of atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease. N-3 PUFAs and their eicosanoid derivatives may play a significant role in modulating the inflammatory response.
- Fish is the major food source of long-chain n-3 PUFAs, including eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), while alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) is a plant n-3 fatty acid mainly found in seeds, nuts, and their oils. Plant sources of n-3 fatty acids cannot currently replace seafood-derived n-3 PUFAs.
- N-3 PUFAs have been shown to have pleiotropic effects by modulating a range of diverse target mechanisms involved in cardiovascular disease development. The GISSI-Prevenzione trial demonstrated that an increased intake of EPA and DHA lowers the risk of coronary heart disease, and the JELIS trial showed that supplementation with EPA decreases major coronary events in Japanese men and women with hypercholesterolemia treated with statins.
</summary>

<summary>

- Rudolf Virchow, a 19th century pathologist, proposed that cancer arises from chronically inflamed cells. Gastric cancer is linked to chronic inflammation, particularly atrophic gastritis and hypochlorhydria.
- Pelayo Correa, a Colombian pathologist, hypothesized a stepwise process for gastric cancer development, starting with chronic atrophic gastritis in the first decade of life. He initially believed environmental factors, such as a diet high in salt and nitrosamines, were responsible.
- In the late 1970s, Robin Warren and Barry Marshall discovered Helicobacter pylori, which was later linked to gastritis and peptic ulcer disease. They speculated that these bacteria might also play a role in gastric cancer.
- Epidemiological studies in the 1980s and 1990s provided weak evidence for a link between H. pylori and gastric cancer. More definitive evidence came from large cohort studies in the 1990s, which found that prior H. pylori infection significantly increased the risk of gastric cancer.
- Since the 1990s, research has focused on understanding the mechanisms of H. pylori-induced gastric carcinogenesis, including genetic susceptibility, H. pylori heterogeneity, and environmental influences.

</summary>

<summary>
• The study compared the functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab and ranibizumab treatments for neovascular age-related macular degeneration (AMD) in Turkish patients on an as-needed treatment regimen.
• The mean BCVA and central retinal thickness (CRT) were significantly improved in both groups compared to baseline at every time point.
• The two groups showed no statistically significant difference in change in BCVA and CRT, injection numbers, or complications.
• Previous studies have reported similar improvements in visual and anatomical outcomes for bevacizumab and ranibizumab treatments for AMD.
</summary>

• The study aimed to evaluate maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with preeclampsia (PE) based on the different values of albumin (25 g/l and < 25 g/l).
• Severe hypoproteinemia (shp) was found to be a significant risk factor for cesarean section (CS), poor maternal outcomes, and poor neonatal outcomes in PE women.
</summary>

The text discusses a study that investigated the relationship between maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with PE based on the different values of albumin. The study found that shp was a significant risk factor for CS, poor maternal outcomes, and poor neonatal outcomes in PE women.

<summary>

- The past 20 years have seen the development of various agents targeting the VEGF-A signaling pathway in cancer, including humanized monoclonal antibodies (such as Avastin) and small-molecule protein tyrosine kinase inhibitors. These agents have provided significant benefits to cancer patients but have limitations, such as the development of resistance and the need for cost-benefit analysis.
- Other VEGF family members, such as VEGF-C and VEGF-D, and other angiogenic factors from distinct growth factor families, have been identified as potential candidates for promoting resistance to Avastin and other anti-angiogenic treatments. These factors, including PIGF, VEGF-B, and VEGF-C/D, have context-dependent activities in cancer and may modulate the effect of VEGF-A.
- Further studies are required to fully understand the complex network of signaling cascades that drive angiogenesis, lymphangiogenesis, and resistance to anti-angiogenic drugs. Genome-wide functional approaches and agents specifically targeting VEGF family members and their receptors are being evaluated for their efficacy as anti-cancer agents.

</summary>

Additional Notes:

- Avastin, a humanized monoclonal antibody to VEGF-A, has been widely used in a range of prevalent human cancers over the past 8 years, typically in combination with cytotoxic chemotherapy.
- Other signaling pathways, such as those driven by members of the PDGF, IGF, and FGF growth factor families, exert control on tumor angiogenesis and may be important in promoting tumor growth. Other alternative molecular targets, such as c-Met, may also be able to affect multiple tumor properties upon hypoxia.
- Recent studies have indicated the role of known inflammatory pathways in enhancing the spread of cancer, opening avenues for the use of existing anti-inflammatory drugs in cancer. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (such as aspirin) have been shown to have anti-cancer effects and could provide a cost-effective and population-based preventative approach to cancer in Asian countries.

- The text describes a study conducted in a low transmission region of Bagh-e Malek in Minab District, Hormozgan Province, Iran, to detect low parasite and asymptomatic malaria infections using microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR.
- The study found that microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR had different levels of sensitivity in detecting malaria infections. While microscopy and RDT missed three asymptomatic P. vivax carriers, nested-PCR identified them.
- The study emphasizes the importance of using multiple malaria detection tools, including molecular methods like nested-PCR, to improve sensitivity, specificity, and reliability for active case surveillance in endemic settings and interrupt malaria transmission in Iran.

</summary>

Additionally, the text mentions that malaria is still a significant public health concern in Iran, particularly in the south and southeast regions. The text also explains that Iran entered the malaria pre-elimination program in 2009 and has implemented various control measures to reduce malaria incidence. The text highlights the importance of active surveillance and precise laboratory methods for detecting all kinds of infections, including asymptomatic ones, to achieve malaria elimination. The text also mentions the limitations of microscopy as the standard malaria diagnosis method and the importance of using RDTs and molecular methods as complementary tools for malaria detection, especially in low transmission areas.

- Over the last two decades, many new immunotherapy approaches for cancer treatment have been developed due to a better understanding of antigen presentation, lymphocyte recognition, and innate immune system functions.
- Some of these agents, such as infusional cytokine therapies for melanoma or renal cell cancer, intravesical BCG therapy for bladder cancer, and active cellular therapy targeting prostatic acid phosphatase (Sipuleucel-T, Provenge, Dendreon) for advanced metastatic prostate cancer, have been approved for standard clinical use.
- Other agents, such as monoclonal antibodies targeting T-cell checkpoint inhibitors like CTLA-4 (Ipilimumab, Bristol-Myers Squibb) for advanced melanoma, have shown benefit in large clinical trials and are anticipated for approval.
- However, evaluating these agents using traditional clinical development paradigms has been challenging due to their potential use in combination with other immune-activating or conventional therapies.
- Biomarkers of biological response are needed to assess the clinical efficacy of these agents, especially for broadly active immune-modulating agents like T-cell checkpoint inhibitors or TLR agonists.
- For antigen-specific vaccines, immune responses to the target antigen have been used as biomarkers of immunological efficacy, but few instances of target antigen immune response have been associated with clinical benefit.
- Machine-learned Bayesian belief networks (ML-BBNs) have been proposed as a method for identifying promising biomarkers and potential biomarker networks.
- In this study, ML-BBNs were used to identify promising biomarkers and then select a subset of features to train a network of immune biomarkers related to observed declines in serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA).
- Sera samples were collected from three separate trials: one with patients treated with androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), one with patients treated with a viral vaccine encoding PSA (PSAV), and one with patients treated with a plasmid DNA vaccine encoding pap (PAPV).
- IgG immune responses could be detected to individual antigens and were associated with individual treatments, suggesting that predictive models

<summary>

- Bone mass density and architecture are dependent on mechanical factors.
- Cell mechanical stimulation promotes osteogenic lineage proliferation and differentiation.
- Stress shielding causes bone loss due to decreased loading, particularly in noncemented prostheses.
- A new approach to this problem is the development of smart implants with bone mechanical stimulation systems.
- The present in vivo study explores the use of the converse piezoelectric effect with PVDF films for effective osteoblast mechanical stimulation.
- The study used PVDF films coated with PMMA and bone-like particles for cell adhesion and electrical insulation.
- The actuator device applied a 5 V square wave of 1 Hz and 3 Hz for 15 minutes at each frequency, once every 24 hours.
- The results showed significant differences in total bone area, immature bone area, and mature bone area around actuated films compared to static controls.
- The increased opn expression around actuators suggests mechanical stress, but further studies are needed to evaluate the bone-material interface and potential effects of the material and electrical current.

</summary>

Additionally, the study used a sheep model, and the results showed qualitative and quantitative statistically significant differences between static and actuated films. However, it is necessary to enlarge the animal study and use a more biocompatible material for ethical reasons. Piezoelectric materials have advantages for actuators in clinical purposes due to their wide range of deformation/displacement, frequencies, and regimens. However, new materials should be developed for better biocompatibility.

- The study compared serum l-fucose levels between 60 oral cancer patients and 30 healthy individuals. The mean value of serum l-fucose levels in oral cancer patients was significantly higher (10.85 mg/dl) compared to healthy individuals (3.47 mg/dl).
- The study also found that serum l-fucose levels increased as oral cancer progressed through different stages, and were positively correlated with tnm stages of oral squamous cell carcinoma (oscc).
</summary>

• LCN2 mice were generated by gene targeting in embryonic stem cells from mouse strain 129 and backcrossed onto the b6 background for 10 generations.
• Heterozygous mating scheme was used to generate wild-type and LCN2 mice for experiments.
• Animals were housed in a specific pathogen-free facility and handled following NIH guidelines.
• Age-matched male wild-type and LCN2 mice were fed either an hfd or regular chow diet for 12 weeks or 3 weeks, respectively.
• LCN2 mice on an hfd gained more body weight and increased adiposity, with higher weights of white and brown fat pads, liver, heart, kidney, and spleen compared to wild-type mice.
• LCN2 mice were more insulin resistant and glucose intolerant than wild-type mice, as shown by increased glucose clearance curves and insulin-stimulated glucose disposal curves.
• LCN2 mice had significantly higher serum levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and free fatty acids on an rcd, and higher levels of ldl and β-hydroxybutyrate on an hfd compared to wild-type mice.
• LCN2 mice had decreased expression of genes involved in lipid metabolism and adipokines, including ppar, lipoprotein lipase (LPL), glut4, adiponectin, and leptin in adipose tissue of hfd-fed mice.
• LCN2 mice had decreased expression of mitochondrial genes involved in mitochondrial biogenesis and oxidative function, such as NRF1, TFAM, ATP5B, COX4, and CPT-1 in bat of hfd-fed mice.

</summary>

<summary>

- Male Wistar rats were used in an experiment to study non-traumatic osteonecrosis of the femoral head.
- The rats were given LPS and methylprednisolone injections, followed by hindlimb unloading and suspension in a head-down tilted position.
- Seven of 11 (63.6%) weight-bearing (wb) rats and six of 11 (54.5%) non-weight-bearing (nwb) rats developed femoral head osteonecrosis.
- No significant difference in osteonecrosis incidence was observed between wb and nwb groups (p = 0.66).
- In both groups, empty lacunae and bone marrow cell necrosis were present in the femoral head.
- In the wb group, fewer fat cells were observed in the medullary space, while in the nwb group, necrotic cell debris accumulated in addition to decreased hematopoietic cells.
- No humeral head osteonecrosis was observed in any rat.
- The study confirmed that weight bearing does not contribute to the development of non-traumatic onfh in rats.
- The rat model may help elucidate the pathogenesis of onfh and devise prevention strategies, but may not be suitable for observing femoral head collapse mechanisms.
- The study revealed that weight bearing is not related to the development of non-traumatic onfh in the rat model, but the etiology, pathogenesis, and prognosis of the condition remain unclear.

</summary>

<summary>

- Nurses' involvement in national health policy processes is important due to their large numbers in the global health workforce and their close relationship with patients. However, historically, nurses have had limited involvement in policy decisions that affect their work environments and professional practice.
- Reasons for nurses' underengagement in policy processes include lack of awareness and knowledge, inadequate skills, and gender differences in the health care system. Nurses are predominantly women, while decision-making positions are held by men.
- Strategies to enhance nurses' engagement in policy processes include assuming formal leadership positions, lobbying and advocacy through professional organizations, and building nurses' understanding of policy and politics through integrated courses in nursing training and fellowship programs.
- The study applied a critical theory perspective to examine nurses' involvement in national health policy processes in Kenya, revealing hierarchies and gender-related issues affecting their participation. The study also suggested ways to improve nurses' involvement, such as enacting legislation to allow nurses with competencies in leadership and policy to hold senior positions, and soliciting their views during policy formulation.

</summary>

- The text describes a study conducted at the neonatal division of Bahrami Children's Hospital in Tehran, Iran, which aimed to determine the frequency of urinary tract infection (UTI) causative organisms in neonates admitted between 2004 and 2012.
- The study found that e. coli was the most prevalent organism causing UTI in neonates, accounting for 64.4% of cases. Enterobacter was the second most common organism, with a relative frequency of 19.2%. E. coli was mostly resistant to ampicillin (93.6%), cefixime (85.7%), and cephalexin (77.3%), but was most susceptible to norfloxacin (100%) and ciprofloxacin (100%).
- The study highlights the importance of continuous assessment of uropathogen epidemiology in the neonatal period, as UTI is difficult to diagnose and could potentially lead to systemic infection with long-term consequences. The study also emphasizes the need for neonatal divisions to take into account the prevailing antibiotic sensitivities of local bacterial isolates before opting for an empirical regimen.

</summary>

<summary>
- The text describes a study investigating white matter changes and temporal lobe structures dysgenesis in patients with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
- The study included 26 patients, aged 16.5-48 years, who were diagnosed with CAH and followed at the department of endocrinology in Mahdia and Sfax, Tunisia.
- Eleven patients (42.3%) showed MRI abnormalities, including white matter hyperintensities, hippocampal dysplasia, and amygdala dysplasia.
- The study suggests that chronic hyperandrogenism due to non-compliance with treatment may be the main mechanism involved in the genesis of brain MRI abnormalities in CAH patients.
</summary>

<summary>

• The human genome draft sequence holds great promise for biomedical advances this century, but navigating the vast genomic data requires universal vocabularies and annotation methods.
• Two main ways of annotating genes are using empirical observations and predicted evolutionary relationships.
• Homology-based annotation relies on the assumption that protein homologs have similar tertiary structures and functions, allowing for predictions based on what is already known about their homologs.
• Homology is not always a perfect indicator of function, as homologs may be related only by evolution and not by molecular mechanism or may have overlapping functions.
• Domain identification plays a significant role in understanding gene function and evolution, as domains represent compact units of protein structure that have survived the tests of time.
• Comparative proteomics and domain analysis have demonstrated the power of relating gene content to the evolution of eukaryotic organisms.
• The Gene Ontology project (GO) and other web-based resources provide a common vocabulary for describing gene function, making it increasingly important to restrict descriptions to a compatible and computational approach.

</summary>

Additionally, the text discusses the importance of orthology prediction and the partitioning of domain families into subfamilies with distinct functions as valuable approaches for navigating genomes. It also mentions the challenges of integrating functional information from large datasets and the future success of genome projects being measured by the opening of new research and therapy avenues.

<summary>

- The text describes a study comparing four commercially available online heart rate monitoring systems for team sports: Polar Team Pro, Acentas Team Monitoring System, Suunto Pro Team Pack, and Activio Sport System.
- The study evaluated the systems' measurement, software, and hardware, with a focus on adequate online measurement of heart rate.
- The evaluation included factors such as measurement accuracy against ECG, installation and use of software and hardware, operating distance, and failure ratio during a soccer match.
- The results showed that Acentas and Polar led in hardware, with Polar having an advantage in storage capacity but decreased wearing performance. Activio offered the most harmonious concept and easiest software installation. Acentas had the best overall performance, but all systems had advantages and disadvantages depending on the specific use case.

</summary>

<summary>

- Stem cells in the lung have been identified throughout the airway based on their ability to self-renew, proliferate, and give rise to diverse cell types in response to injury. These stem cells have been linked to the initiation and growth of lung cancers, particularly squamous cell carcinoma and small cell lung carcinoma.
- The identification and isolation of lung stem cells have provided insights into the role of stem cells in lung repair and their potential role in lung tumorigenesis. Ongoing research aims to better understand the relationship between healthy stem cells and lung cancer, as well as the tumor microenvironment and lung cancer stem cells, to improve the management of lung tumors.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study evaluates the role of urethral plate characters, such as shape and width, in the success of tip urethroplasty for primary anterior penile hypospadias in 100 children.
• The study found that patients with urethral plates wider than 8 mm had a lower incidence of fistulas and successful 8 fr calibration compared to those with plates narrower than 8 mm. Narrow plates may be inadequate for creating a neourethra, leading to increased tension on the suture line and higher fistula formation.
</summary>

<summary>

- The study aimed to develop a prototype to measure the bracket debonding force in vivo using a strain gauge connected directly to the pliers.
- The prototype consisted of a modified plier, a measurement and control circuit, and a specific software.
- The modified plier received an intermediate part between the active arm and the claw, where a strain gauge was connected.
- The measurement and control circuit performed the reading of the strain gauge and changed the obtained value into an 8-bit binary number.
- The software was programmed in C and designed for research use, with a calibration system and a simple linear regression analysis.
- The accuracy and precision of the prototype were measured using weights from 1 to 6 kg, with no significant differences between examiners.
- The mean bond strength obtained with the prototype (2.96 mpa) and in a universal testing machine (3.08 mpa) were statistically similar.
- The adhesive remnant index (ARI) showed that score 3 was predominant in both groups, indicating that the composite resin remained completely bonded to the enamel after bracket debonding.
- Debonding with the prototype was a safe method for preserving the enamel surface.
- The study suggests that the prototype might be a useful tool for measuring bond strength in vivo.

</summary>

- The study found that older women, women with less education, single women, women who reported unprotected sex with a non-steady partner, and women who reported multiple sex partners were more likely to have trichomonas vaginalis infection.
- The study also highlighted the importance of screening and treating trichomonas vaginalis in socially marginalized young women from low-income communities in coastal Peru, as they are a high-risk population for maintaining endemic infections at the population level. The asymptomatic nature of the infection and the lack of a direct relationship between symptoms and infection make syndromic management ineffective, and the long-term prevalence of infection in older women suggests a need for screening and treatment programs.
</summary>

<summary>

- Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS) is a symptomatic generalized epilepsy syndrome characterized by tonic, atonic, and atypical absence seizures, slow spike wave discharges on EEG, and cognitive impairment.
- LGS affects children, with an onset between 2 and 5 years, and boys being more commonly affected.
- The prognosis is poor, with seizures and cognitive outcome being affected by symptomatic etiology, history of nonconvulsive status epilepticus, prior infantile spasms, and early age of seizure onset.
- Valproic acid is the most commonly used initial medication for drop attacks, atypical absences, and myoclonic seizures in LGS.
- Rufinamide, a triazole derivative, is an orphan drug granted for the adjunctive treatment of LGS and partial seizures in adults and adolescents.
- Rufinamide's mechanism of action involves decreased firing of high frequency sodium-dependent action potentials and prolongation of sodium channel inactivation.
- Rufinamide has a wide spectrum of anticonvulsant effectiveness and a good safety profile, with minimal cognitive side effects and behavioral toxicity.
- A single double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial showed that rufinamide significantly decreases total seizures and tonic-atonic seizures in LGS patients.
- Further studies are needed to establish rufinamide's role in the overall treatment algorithm for LGS and its relationship to prior drugs with reported effectiveness.

</summary>

<summary>

- Interpopulational variations in sexual chemical signals from the femoral glands of iberian wall lizards (Podarcis hispanica) may lead to reproductive isolation and cryptic speciation.
- The iberian wall lizard is a small diurnal lizard living in rocky habitats of the Iberian Peninsula, and molecular and morphological studies suggest cryptic speciation within this species.
- Chemical cues from males and females are important in intraspecific communication and mate choice.
- Five distinct populations of iberian wall lizards in central Spain were selected based on morphological and genetic differences.
- Morphological measurements were taken, including body mass, body size, head length, head depth, number of femoral pores, and number of blue ocelli.
- Femoral gland secretions were extracted and analyzed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) to identify lipophilic compounds.
- Tongue-flick experiments were conducted to test for chemosensory recognition between populations.
- Males and females discriminated between scents of lizards from their own population and those from other populations, with some populations showing a clear preference for scents of females from their own population.
- The results suggest that at least some populations of iberian wall lizards may be reproductively isolated and undergoing cryptic speciation due to differences in chemical signals.
</summary>

<summary>

- The scientific activity of researchers is measured through published papers in peer-reviewed journals, with Medline/PubMed being the most commonly used database.
- Medline/PubMed, Web of Science, Embase, and Current Contents are major international databases for health sciences research. In Brazil, Lilacs and SciELO are the main databases.
- Publications by researchers reflect the productivity and influence of their institutions. The number of citations received by articles published in journals is used to determine their impact factor (IF).
- The text describes an analysis of publications by full professors at the Universidade de São Paulo's Faculdade de Medicina between 2001 and 2006. The study found that 1,960 articles were published in 630 international and national journals, with an average of 5.9 articles per professor per year.
- The analysis revealed that 62.3% of articles had 4 to 7 authors, and 93% of articles had co-authors from the same institution. The majority of articles were published in international journals, with 47.7% having IFs between 1 and 5.
- The study also found that 27 of the articles were cited more than 50 times, and the collective publications of the Faculdade de Medicina da Universidade de São Paulo were among the 100 most cited in the world.

</summary>

<summary>

- According to WHO experts, if rubella infection occurs during early pregnancy, the risk of passing the virus to the fetus is about 90%.
- Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) is the most significant complication of rubella, which affects approximately 110,000 infants each year in developing countries.
- Rubella vaccination aims to prevent congenital infection with rubella virus and CRS.
- The most commonly used vaccine globally is the ra27/3 virus strain, which induces immunity in 95% of vaccinated persons.
- In Iran, a study in 2006 revealed a significant increase in rubella immunity (19.7%) among vaccinated versus unvaccinated girls.
- Mass rubella vaccination caused a significant decrease in the rate of negative antibody from 20.42% to 0.7%.
- The effectiveness of the ra27/3 vaccine is demonstrated by the elimination of rubella and CRS from the western hemisphere and high vaccination coverage in several European countries.
- Continued rubella vaccination in Iran as part of the national vaccination program has resulted in increased anti-rubella antibodies and immunity in high-risk populations, such as premarital girls.

</summary>

<summary>

• Whole mount in situ hybridization (WISH) using gene-specific RNA probes is widely used in developmental research for analyzing gene expression patterns and cell positioning.
• The technique was initially performed using radioactive probes but was simplified with the use of nonradioactive probes.
• Fluorescent methods for detecting transcripts may overcome the limitation of overlapping regions of expression in multilabeling techniques.
• Quantum dots (QDs) are a new type of inorganic fluorophore with ideal optical properties for use in biology, including strong fluorescent signal emission, narrow and tunable emission spectra, large separation between excitation and emission, and resistance to photobleaching.
• QDs have been used for in situ hybridization in clinical biopsies and have shown to significantly improve rna detection sensitivity.
• Proteinase K treatment can render xenopus embryos permeable to allow QD penetration deep within embryonic tissues, enabling specific deep tissue staining.
• The use of QDs for nonamplified fluorescent whole mount in situ hybridization in xenopos embryos suggests that QD whole-mount in situ hybridization will find successful applications in most developmental models.

</summary>

<summary>

• Pancreatic cancer is a deadly disease with low survival rates and approximately 44,000 new diagnoses per year in the US.
• The most common type of pancreatic cancer is pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), which has the most aggressive tumor biology and metastatic potential.
• The median survival time after PDAC diagnosis is about four months, and only 19% of patients survive past one year and 2% survive past five years.
• Demographic and clinical factors, such as gender, race, age, marital status, tumor size, nodal status, and distant metastases, influence the survival of PDAC patients.
• Surgical resection of the tumor, with or without adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation, is the most effective treatment for PDAC, but only 20% of patients are suitable candidates.
• Cox proportional hazards regression models were used to estimate the impact of risk factors on the survival of PDAC patients and develop nomograms for predicting survival and perioperative mortality.
• The reliability and generalizability of the models were assessed by calibration and discrimination abilities, cross-validation, and validation on external datasets.

</summary>
